title: Creating Dappled Light for Fashion Photography
summary: Photographer Lindsay Adler breaks down a fashion shoot utilizing the Westcott Optical Spot to create a dappled lighting effect. The tutorial covers the concept of monochromatic styling, the specific lighting setup involving projection and bounce flash, camera settings, and the post-processing workflow to achieve a moody, editorial look.

steps.action: Select a hand-painted canvas with heavy texture to prevent the subject from blending into the monochromatic background.
Set up the key light using a strobe equipped with an optical spot modifier on the right side of the frame.
Swap the kit lens on the optical spot for a wider zoom lens (24-70mm) using an EF mount adapter to light the subject head-to-toe.
Insert a 'leaves' gobo into the optical spot and soft-focus the lens to create undefined, natural-looking pockets of light.
Set up a second strobe on the left with a zoom reflector, pointing it directly at the ceiling to create a broad, soft, top-down fill light.
Configure camera settings to f/4.0 to slightly blur the textured background for separation.
In post-processing, increase contrast and clarity, darken the exposure, and desaturate the image.
Color grade the image by shifting green hues and adding yellow to the skin tones for an analogous color palette.
Retouch the image by extending the background, smoothing skin texture, and removing clothing wrinkles.

key_takeaways: Using a standard camera lens on an optical spot modifier allows for wider light coverage compared to included kit lenses.
Soft-focusing a gobo pattern creates a more natural, dappled light effect rather than a sharp projection.
Bouncing a strobe off a high ceiling is an effective way to create a large, soft fill source that mimics natural overhead light.
Color grading is essential in monochromatic shoots to unify the tones of the subject and background.
